Award.AwardTitle: AGS-PRF: Reconciling Atmospheric Temperature Observations and Understanding Climate Feedbacks
Award.AbstractNarration:
Monitoring Earth's climate requires a lengthy record of global observations. Satellite remote sensing technologies provide global coverage of observations at a high spatio-temporal resolution. Due to the relatively short life span of between 8-10 years for the individual satellites, one needs to combine the observation records of multiple satellites that were launched at different eras for monitoring and understanding climate changes. The challenging of using satellite observations for climate studies is that one needs to remove/reduce inconsistencies or biases within a satellite mission due to orbital drifting and between continuous satellite missions with the same sensors due to changes of orbital parameters, besides the need of inter-satellite calibration/validation of different sensors. One of the two main objectives of this funded project is to systematically identify and correct climate scale biases/drifts in microwave brightness temperature measurements of satellites in both troposphere and stratosphere using other observation records. The PI has developed and demonstrated the key methodologies for this funded research in his dissertation research.

The funded project will also take a fresh new look at this challenging question: what causes large uncertainties in projecting climate change using climate models? The PI plans to explore if and how the strength of climate feedbacks in climate models are linked to the models? own climate states. If a linkage to the models? climate feedbacks and the models? mean states can be identified, the future global warming projection uncertainties can be reduced by using such observations to constraint models mean states.

The proposed research will advance our understanding of sources based on biases in both observations and climate models which will enable better decision-making.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Earth's climate is changing in response to the rapid accumulation of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, which is caused by human activities. The signatures of climate change include warming of the surface and lower atmosphere, global-scale melting of glaciers, and shifting patterns of rainfall. Such modifications to Earth's climate have important implications for the wellbeing of ecosystems, human health, and food security. It is therefore important to accurately monitor changes in our climate and to improve predictions of future climate conditions. This research project contributes to the improvement of historical climate observations and future predictions of climate change.

To increase the reliability of observed climate records, we assessed data from the microwave sounding unit (MSU). The MSU (and its successor the advanced MSU, AMSU) are satellite based instruments that measure microwave emissions from atmospheric oxygen molecules. The strength of these emissions is closely related to the temperature in broad atmospheric layers. Such measurements of atmospheric temperature have been made onboard over a dozen satellites since late-1978, which can be combined into a continuous, 40+ year global time series.

Given their length and global coverage, MSU/AMSU observations represent a key climate record. Unfortunately, it has been noted that AMSU measurements made since the late 1990s tend to exhibit cooling compared to alternate measurements of atmospheric temperature. In order to compare satellite microwave temperature measurements with temperature measurement from weather balloons, long-term weather model simulations (known as reanalysis models), and alternate satellite products (e.g., the atmospheric infrared sounder), we implemented a radiative transfer model that could convert the temperature at discrete atmospheric layers into an estimated microwave radiance. In comparing individual AMSU satellite records with complementary measurements of atmospheric temperature change, we were able to identify time periods in which records diverge and note possible reasons for such differences across datasets. Follow-on work is planned to remove potential biases in the atmospheric temperature record.

Another component of this project is to improve understanding of future climate change. Future changes in climate are estimated using global climate models (GCMs), which simulate the Earth's response to increasing concentrations of atmospheric greenhouse gases. Global climate models are employed by research institutions in many countries and several dozen GCMs exist. Although all models project substantial warming in response to greenhouse gas emissions, the magnitude of the warming varies widely, which limits our ability to precisely predict future changes in the Earth's climate.

In this work, we evaluated how a model's representation of the current, observed climate influences the simulation of future climate change. We showed that biases in simulations of the current climate are important. For example, some climate models contain more Antarctic sea ice than the modern, observed sea ice extent. When such models warm in response to increasing greenhouse gas concentrations, they tend to lose a substantial amount of sea ice. The opposite is true of models that have too little Antarctic sea ice compared to present-day observations; these GCMs lose relatively little sea ice. Similar relationships also exist for clouds and relative humidity: biases today have a predictable impact on simulations of future climate. Such biases contribute to the wide range of future climates predicted by climate models. This work highlights the need for both accurate observations and for models to reproduce the observed, current climate.

In order to engage young people in science and technology, the principal investigator (PI) helped teach middle school students programming skills via the Girls Who Code Program. Using skills developed as part of this research, the PI also contributed to an open-source project to improve electronic medical records software deployed in Africa. To increase awareness of climate change, the PI presented publicly about the impacts of climate change and engaged students with hands-on climate experiments at youth science conferences. Last, the PI also fact checked and analyzed media reporting about climate change on the website Climate Feedback, which helps the public digest nuanced information regarding climate change.
